edu.rit.pj2

Class Job

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.rit.pj2.Job
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    BCAClu, CCAClu, HamCycClu, MandelbrotClu, MineCoinClu, MineCoinClu2, MineCoinClu3, MinVerCovClu3, MinVerCovDist, PiClu, PjmrJob, ScatterFiles, ScatterLines, Test07, Test08, Test09, Test10, Test11, Test12, Test13, Test14, Test15, Test16, TotientClu, ZombieClu

    public abstract class Job
extends Object
    Class Job is the abstract base class for a PJ2 job. A PJ2 parallel program is either a single task (a subclass of class Task) or is a number of tasks grouped together into a job (a subclass of class Job). A PJ2 program is executed by running the PJ2 launcher program, pj2.

    Programming a job. To set up a job:

    • Write a subclass of class Job.

    • In the Job subclass's main() method, call the rule() method one or more times to define the job's rules. See class Rule for further information about defining rules.

    • Optionally, call the putTuple() method to put initial tuples into tuple space.

    • Optionally, specify the job's properties by calling the threads(), schedule(), chunk(), nodeName(), cores(), gpus(), workers(), masterSchedule(), masterChunk(), trackerHost(), trackerPort(), listenHost(), listenPort(), debug(), jvmFlags(), and timeLimit() methods.

    Running a job. To run a job, type this command:

    $ java pj2 jar=file MainJob arg ...

    The above command runs class MainJob, a subclass of class Job. Replace MainJob with the fully-qualified class name of the desired job subclass. The pj2 program creates an instance of the job subclass, then calls the job's main() method, passing in an array of the command line argument strings (zero or more). The main() method defines one or more Rules that specify Tasks that carry out the computation. (The jar=file option is described later.)

    Job execution. After calling the job's main() method, the pj2 program proceeds to execute the job. The job maintains a repository of Tuples known as tuple space. The job's execution is driven by firing the job's rules, based on tuples that are written into tuple space. There are three kinds of rules:

    • Start rule—A rule that fires once when the job starts.

    • On-demand rule—A rule that fires when a certain tuple or tuples are present in tuple space.

    • Finish rule—A rule that fires once when the job finishes.

    Each rule has an associated task group consisting of one or more tasks. When a rule fires, for each task in the rule's task group, an instance of the task is constructed, and the task's main() method is called to carry out the task's computation. For an on-demand rule, the tuples that caused the rule to fire are automatically taken out of tuple space and are provided to all tasks in the rule's task group. Any task may also read or take tuples from tuple space as it executes. Any task may put tuples into tuple space, which may trigger further rules to fire. For further information about the criteria for firing rules and the actions performed when firing rules, see class Rule.

    The tasks in a rule's task group are guaranteed to start at the same time. If there are not sufficient idle resources to execute all the tasks when the rule fires, the tasks are put in a queue. Later, when sufficient idle resources become available, the tasks are taken out of the queue and started all at once.

    Tuple space occupies memory solely inside the job's process. The Java Virtual Machine that runs the job must be configured with a heap size large enough to hold the tuples that exist in tuple space at each instant.

    Tracker host and port. A job's tasks are executed on one or more nodes. There is a Tracker that keeps track of which jobs and tasks are executing on which nodes, that assigns newly created tasks to execute on available nodes, and that maintains the queue of tasks waiting for resources to become available. By default, the Tracker listens for connections on one of the local machine's network interfaces and port 20618. By default, the Job tries to set up a connection to the Tracker on each of the local machine's network interfaces and port 20618, stopping as soon as it successfully establishes a connection. You can override the default and specify a particular Tracker host on the Job's pj2 command line as follows:

    $ java pj2 tracker=host MainJob arg ...

    You can specify a particular Tracker host and port on the Job's pj2 command line as follows:

    $ java pj2 tracker=host:port MainJob arg ...

    If the job cannot set up a connection to the Tracker host and port, or if tracker=none was specified, the job falls back to executing all tasks in the same process as the job itself. In this case there is no coordination among separate jobs. For further information about the Tracker, see package edu.rit.pj2.tracker.

    Listening host and port. The job itself listens to a certain host and port for connections from the nodes executing the job's tasks. By default, the job listens to the same IP address as the Tracker connection and an unused port. You can specify a particular listening host on the Job's pj2 command line as follows:

    $ java pj2 listen=host MainJob arg ...

    You can specify a particular listening host and port on the Job's pj2 command line as follows:

    $ java pj2 listen=host:port MainJob arg ...

    Firewalls. If the job's host is running a firewall, the firewall must be configured to allow incoming connections to the job's listening host and port.

    JAR file. The jar=file option specifies the Java archive (JAR) file that contains the Java class files for the job and all its tasks. This JAR file does not include the PJ2 Library classes. This JAR file is automatically added to the pj2 program's Java class path. In addition, when a task is executed on a node, this JAR file is sent to the node and is automatically added to the Java class path of the process that is executing the task. An instance of class JarClassLoader is used to load classes and resources from the JAR file. If the jar=file option is not specified, no JAR file is sent to the node, which means the node might not be able to load the classes needed to execute the task. (The jar=file option might not be needed if the nodes can obtain the necessary classes another way.) The JAR file can also be specified by calling the jar() method.

    Debugging messages. A job can print various debugging messages on the standard error stream. Call the debug() method to specify the debugging message(s) to print. You can also specify debugging message(s) on the pj2 command line as follows, where message is one of the debugging messages in enum Debug:

    $ java pj2 debug=message[,message...] MainJob arg ...

    I/O in a job. Code in a job can print on System.out or System.err, and the printouts appear on the job's process's console as usual. Code in a task launched by a job can also print on System.out or System.err, and the printouts are automatically redirected to the job's process's console. The printouts actually appear on the console when the job terminates; to make the printouts appear earlier, call System.out.flush() or System.err.flush().

    Other I/O, such as reading from the job's standard input, reading files, and writing files, might need to be done in a task that runs in the job's process. This would be necessary, for example, if tasks running on separate nodes do not run in the user's account and so cannot access the user's files. In such cases:

    • To read the standard input or the contents of a file, include rule(s) in the job that execute task(s) that read the data from the desired source. These task(s) must be specified with runInJobProcess() to ensure that the task(s) have access to the job's standard input or the files in the user's account. These task(s) put the data into their output tuple(s). Also include rule(s) in the job that match these tuple(s) and that execute task(s) to process the data. These task(s) obtain the data from their input tuple(s).

    • To write the contents of a file, include rule(s) in the job that that execute task(s) to generate the data to be written. These task(s) put the data into their output tuple(s). Also include rule(s) in the job that match these tuple(s) and that execute task(s) to write the data to the desired destination. These task(s) must be specified with runInJobProcess() to ensure that the task(s) have access to files in the user's account. These task(s) obtain the data from their input tuple(s).

    JVM heap size in a job. When one of the job's tasks is executed on a node, by default, the Java Virtual Machine (JVM) that will run the task is created with the java command. This means that the maximum JVM heap size will be set to the default size. If the task needs, say, a 2-gigabyte heap instead, call the jvmFlags("-Xmx2000m") method in the TaskSpec in the Rule that launches the task. Then the JVM that will run the task is created with the java -Xmx2000m command, which sets the maximum JVM heap size to 2 gigabytes. (You can specify any desired JVM flags for the task in this manner.)

    You can specify JVM flags for all tasks in the job by calling the job's jvmFlags() method. You can also specify JVM flags for all tasks in the job by including the jvmFlags parameter on the pj2 command line. (Specifying an individual task spec's JVM flags overrides those of the job.)

    Abnormal termination. If code in a job or task throws an exception that propagates out of the main() method, the pj2 program prints an exception stack trace and terminates.

    Code in a job or task must not call the System.exit() method. If a job or task needs to terminate itself, the job or task should throw an exception that propagates out of every method without being caught, such as a TerminateException or any other runtime exception. The exception's detail message can explain why the job or task terminated. This exception propagates out of the main() method and causes the pj2 program to terminate.

      • fixed

        public static final Schedule fixed
        Fixed schedule. The iterations are partitioned into as many chunks as there are threads. Each chunk is the same size (except possibly the last chunk). Each thread performs a different chunk of iterations. The chunk property is not used.

        A fixed schedule is appropriate when each loop iteration takes the same amount of time, so load balancing is not needed; and when each thread should do a contiguous range of loop indexes.

        See Also:
        Schedule.fixed

      • leapfrog

        public static final Schedule leapfrog
        Leapfrog schedule. Let the loop index lower bound be L and the number of threads be K; then thread 0 performs the iterations for indexes L, L+K, L+2K, ...; thread 1 performs the iterations for indexes L+1, L+1+K, L+1+2K, ...; thread 2 performs the iterations for indexes L+2, L+2+K, L+2+2K, ...; and so on. The chunk property is not used.

        A leapfrog schedule is appropriate when each loop iteration takes the same amount of time, so load balancing is not needed; and when each thread should do noncontiguous loop indexes with a stride of K.

        See Also:
        Schedule.leapfrog

      • dynamic

        public static final Schedule dynamic
        Dynamic schedule. The iterations are partitioned into chunks. Each chunk is the same size (except possibly the last chunk) as specified by the chunk property. If the chunk property is STANDARD_CHUNK, a chunk size of 1 is used. The threads execute the chunks in a dynamic fashion: when a thread has finished executing a chunk, the thread gets the next available chunk and executes it.

        A dynamic schedule is appropriate when each loop iteration takes a different amount of time, so load balancing is needed. However, be careful when choosing the chunk size. A smaller chunk size can yield a better balanced load; a larger chunk size requires less thread synchronization overhead.

        See Also:
        Schedule.dynamic

      • proportional

        public static final Schedule proportional
        Proportional schedule. The iterations are partitioned into chunks. Each chunk is the same size (except possibly the last chunk). The chunk property specifies the chunk factor. If the chunk property is STANDARD_CHUNK, a chunk factor of 10 is used. The number of chunks is the number of threads times the chunk factor. The chunk size is the number of iterations divided by the number of chunks. The threads execute the chunks in a dynamic fashion: when a thread has finished executing a chunk, the thread gets the next available chunk and executes it.

        A proportional schedule is appropriate when each loop iteration takes a different amount of time, so load balancing is needed. However, be careful when choosing the chunk factor. A larger chunk factor can yield a better balanced load; a smaller chunk factor requires less thread synchronization overhead.

        See Also:
        Schedule.proportional

      • guided

        public static final Schedule guided
        Guided schedule. The iterations are partitioned into chunks. The chunks are of different sizes; earlier chunks are larger, later chunks are smaller. The minimum chunk size is specified by the chunk property. If the chunk property is STANDARD_CHUNK, a minimum chunk size of 1 is used. The threads execute the chunks in a dynamic fashion: when a thread has finished executing a chunk, the thread gets the next available chunk and executes it.

        A guided schedule is appropriate when each loop iteration takes a different amount of time, so load balancing is needed. However, be careful when choosing the minimum chunk size. A smaller minimum chunk size can yield a better balanced load; a larger minimum chunk size requires less thread synchronization overhead.

        See Also:
        Schedule.guided

      • jobLaunch

        public static final Debug jobLaunch
        Debug printout when the job is launched. Includes the job ID, time, and date. On by default.
        See Also:

      • makespan

        public static final Debug makespan
        Debug printout of the job's makespan. This is the elapsed time from when the first task actually started until when the last task actually finished. This might be different from the job's elapsed time if the job sat in the Tracker queue for a while. Off by default.
        See Also:
        Debug.makespan

      • main

        public abstract void main(String[] args)
                   throws Exception
        Configure the rules and other settings for this job.

        Warning: The main() method is intended to be called only by the pj2 launcher program. Do not call the main() method yourself.

        Parameters:
        args - Array of zero or more command line argument strings.
        Throws:
        Exception - The main() method can throw any exception.

                   throws Exception
        Execute this job.

        Warning: The execute() method is intended to be called only by the pj2 launcher program. Do not call the execute() method yourself.

        Throws:
        Exception - The execute() method can throw any exception.

      • rule

        public Rule rule()
        Add a rule to this job. The rule() method returns the rule. Call methods on the returned Rule object to configure the rule.
        Returns:
        Rule.

      • rule

        public Rule rule(Action<Rule> action)
        Add a rule to this job and configure the rule. The given Action's run() method is called, passing in the rule; the run() method can configure the rule. The rule() method then returns the rule. If necessary, call methods on the returned Rule object to further configure the rule.
        Parameters:
        action - Action.
        Returns:
        Rule.

        public void putTuple(int copies,
            Tuple tuple)

        Parameters:

        tuple - Tuple.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if tuple is null.
        IllegalArgumentException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if copies < 0.

      • masterFor

        public <T extends Task> TaskSpec masterFor(int lb,
                                  int ub,
                                  Class<T> taskClass)
        Add a master-worker cluster parallel for loop to this job, with a loop index of type int. To complete the master-worker cluster parallel for loop, the worker task must call the workerFor() method. For further information, see class WorkerParallelForLoop.

        If lb > ub, it represents a loop with no iterations. If lb ≤ ub, it represents a loop with one or more iterations.

        Warning: There can be only one master-worker cluster parallel for loop in a job.

        Type Parameters:
        T - Worker task data type.
        Parameters:
        lb - Loop index lower bound.
        ub - Loop index upper bound.
        taskClass - Worker task class.
        Returns:
        Task specification for the worker task class.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if taskClass is null.

      • masterFor

        public <T extends Task> TaskSpec masterFor(long lb,
                                  long ub,
                                  Class<T> taskClass)
        Add a master-worker cluster parallel for loop to this job, with a loop index of type long. To complete the master-worker cluster parallel for loop, the worker task must call the workerFor() method. For further information, see class WorkerParallelForLoop.

        If lb > ub, it represents a loop with no iterations. If lb ≤ ub, it represents a loop with one or more iterations.

        Warning: There can be only one master-worker cluster parallel for loop in a job.

        Type Parameters:
        T - Worker task data type.
        Parameters:
        lb - Loop index lower bound.
        ub - Loop index upper bound.
        taskClass - Worker task class.
        Returns:
        Task specification for the worker task class.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if taskClass is null.

      • threads

        public void threads(int threads)
        Set this job's threads property. The threads property specifies the number of threads that will execute a parallel for loop.

        The job's threads property specifies the threads property for each task in the job. Specifying the threads property for a particular task overrides the job's threads property for that task.

        Parameters:
        threads - Number of threads (≥ 1), THREADS_EQUALS_CORES, or DEFAULT_THREADS.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if threads is illegal.
        See Also:
        Task.threads(int), threads()

      • threads

        public int threads()
        Get this job's threads property. The threads property specifies the number of threads that will execute a parallel for loop. The default is one thread for each core of the machine on which the program is running.
        Returns:
        Number of threads (≥ 1), or THREADS_EQUALS_CORES.
        See Also:
        Task.threads(), threads(int)

      • schedule

        public void schedule(Schedule schedule)
        Set this job's schedule property. The schedule property, along with the chunk property, specifies how the iterations of a parallel for loop are partitioned among the threads executing the parallel for loop. Refer to enum Schedule for descriptions of the possible schedules.

        The job's schedule property specifies the schedule property for each task in the job. Specifying the schedule property for a particular task overrides the job's schedule property for that task.

        Parameters:
        schedule - Parallel for loop schedule, or DEFAULT_SCHEDULE.
        See Also:
        Task.schedule(Schedule), schedule(), chunk(int), chunk()

      • schedule

        public Schedule schedule()
        Get this job's schedule property. The schedule property, along with the chunk property, specifies how the iterations of a parallel for loop are partitioned among the threads executing the parallel for loop. The default is a fixed schedule.
        Returns:
        Parallel for loop schedule.
        See Also:
        Task.schedule(), schedule(Schedule), chunk()

      • chunk

        public void chunk(int chunk)
        Set this job's chunk property. The chunk property, along with the schedule property, specifies how the iterations of a parallel for loop are partitioned among the threads executing the parallel for loop. Refer to enum Schedule for descriptions of the possible schedules.

        The job's chunk property specifies the chunk property for each task in the job. Specifying the chunk property for a particular task overrides the job's chunk property for that task.

        Parameters:
        chunk - Chunk size (≥ 1), STANDARD_CHUNK, or DEFAULT_CHUNK.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if chunk is illegal.
        See Also:
        Task.chunk(int), schedule(Schedule), schedule(), chunk()

      • chunk

        public int chunk()
        Get this job's chunk property. The chunk property, along with the schedule property, specifies how the iterations of a parallel for loop are partitioned among the threads executing the parallel for loop. The default is the standard chunk size for the schedule property; see enum Schedule for further information.
        Returns:
        Chunk size (≥ 1), or STANDARD_CHUNK.
        See Also:
        Task.chunk(), chunk(int), schedule()

      • nodeName

        public void nodeName(String nodeName)
        Set this job's nodeName property. The nodeName property specifies the name of the cluster node on which a task must run.

        The job's nodeName property specifies the nodeName property for each task in the job. Specifying the nodeName property for a particular task overrides the job's nodeName property for that task.

        Parameters:
        nodeName - Node name, ANY_NODE_NAME, or DEFAULT_NODE_NAME.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if nodeName is null.
        See Also:
        nodeName()

      • nodeName

        public String nodeName()
        Get this job's nodeName property. The nodeName property specifies the name of the cluster node on which a task must run. The default is that a task can run on any node of the cluster.
        Returns:
        Node name, or ANY_NODE_NAME.
        See Also:
        nodeName(String)

      • cores

        public void cores(int cores)
        Set this job's cores property. The cores property specifies the number of CPU cores a task requires.

        The job's cores property specifies the cores property for each task in the job. Specifying the cores property for a particular task overrides the job's cores property for that task.

        Parameters:
        cores - Number of cores (≥ 1), ALL_CORES, or DEFAULT_CORES.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if cores is illegal.
        See Also:
        cores()

      • cores

        public int cores()
        Get this task's cores property. The cores property specifies the number of CPU cores a task requires. The default is that a task requires all the cores on the node.
        Returns:
        Number of cores (≥ 1), or ALL_CORES.
        See Also:
        cores(int)

      • gpus

        public void gpus(int gpus)
        Set this job's gpus property. The gpus property specifies the number of GPU accelerators a task requires.

        The job's gpus property specifies the gpus property for each task in the job. Specifying the gpus property for a particular task overrides the job's gpus property for that task.

        Parameters:
        gpus - Number of GPUs (≥ 0), ALL_GPUS, or DEFAULT_GPUS.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if gpus is illegal.
        See Also:
        gpus()

      • gpus

        public int gpus()
        Get this job's gpus property. The gpus property specifies the number of GPU accelerators a task requires. The default is none (0).
        Returns:
        Number of GPUs (≥ 0), or ALL_GPUS.
        See Also:
        gpus(int)

      • workers

        public void workers(int workers)
        Set this job's workers property. The workers property specifies the number of worker tasks that will execute a master-worker cluster parallel for loop.
        Parameters:
        workers - Number of worker tasks (≥ 1), or DEFAULT_WORKERS.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if workers is illegal.
        See Also:
        workers()

      • workers

        public int workers()
        Get this job's workers property. The workers property specifies the number of worker tasks that will execute a master-worker cluster parallel for loop. The default is one worker task.
        Returns:
        Number of workers (≥ 1).
        See Also:
        workers(int)

      • masterSchedule

        public void masterSchedule(Schedule schedule)
        Set this job's masterSchedule property. The masterSchedule property, along with the masterChunk property, specifies how the iterations of a master-worker cluster parallel for loop are partitioned among the worker tasks executing the parallel for loop. Refer to enum Schedule for descriptions of the possible schedules.
        Parameters:
        schedule - Parallel for loop schedule, or DEFAULT_SCHEDULE.
        See Also:
        masterSchedule(), masterChunk(int), masterChunk()

      • masterSchedule

        public Schedule masterSchedule()
        Get this job's masterSchedule property. The masterSchedule property, along with the masterChunk property, specifies how the iterations of a master-worker cluster parallel for loop are partitioned among the worker tasks executing the parallel for loop. The default is a fixed schedule.
        Returns:
        Parallel for loop schedule.
        See Also:
        masterSchedule(Schedule), masterChunk()

      • masterChunk

        public void masterChunk(int chunk)
        Set this job's masterChunk property. The masterChunk property, along with the masterSchedule property, specifies how the iterations of a master-worker cluster parallel for loop are partitioned among the worker tasks executing the parallel for loop. Refer to enum Schedule for descriptions of the possible schedules.
        Parameters:
        chunk - Chunk size (≥ 1), STANDARD_CHUNK, or DEFAULT_CHUNK.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if chunk is illegal.
        See Also:
        masterSchedule(Schedule), masterSchedule(), masterChunk()

      • masterChunk

        public int masterChunk()
        Get this job's masterChunk property. The masterChunk property, along with the masterSchedule property, specifies how the iterations of a master-worker cluster parallel for loop are partitioned among the worker tasks executing the parallel for loop. The default is the standard chunk size for the schedule property; see enum Schedule for further information.
        Returns:
        Chunk size (≥ 1), or STANDARD_CHUNK.
        See Also:
        masterChunk(int), masterSchedule()

      • trackerHost

        public void trackerHost(String host)
        Set this job's trackerHost property. The trackerHost property specifies the host name at which the Tracker is listening for connections.
        Parameters:
        host - Host name.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if host is null.
        See Also:
        trackerPort(int)

      • trackerHost

        public String trackerHost()
        Get this job's trackerHost property. The trackerHost property specifies the host name at which the Tracker is listening for connections. If set to "none", the job will not connect to the Tracker. If not set, the job will try to connect to the Tracker on each of the local machine's network interfaces, stopping as soon as a connection is successfully established.
        Returns:
        Host name.
        See Also:
        trackerPort()

      • trackerPort

        public void trackerPort(int port)
        Set this job's trackerPort property. The trackerPort property specifies the port number at which the Tracker is listening for connections.
        Parameters:
        port - Port number (0 .. 65535).
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if port is illegal.
        See Also:
        trackerHost(String)

      • trackerPort

        public int trackerPort()
        Get this job's trackerPort property. The trackerPort property specifies the port number at which the Tracker is listening for connections. If not set, the default is 20618.
        Returns:
        Port number (0 .. 65535).
        See Also:
        trackerHost()

      • listenHost

        public void listenHost(String host)
        Set this job's listenHost property. The listenHost property specifies the host name at which the job itself will listen for connections.
        Parameters:
        host - Host name, or null to use the default.
        See Also:
        listenPort(int)

      • listenHost

        public String listenHost()
        Get this job's listenHost property. The listenHost property specifies the host name at which the job itself will listen for connections. If not set, the default is to use the same IP address as the job's connection to the Tracker.
        Returns:
        Host name, or null if not set.
        See Also:
        listenPort()

      • listenPort

        public void listenPort(int port)
        Set this job's listenPort property. The listenPort property specifies the port number at which the job itself will listen for connections.
        Parameters:
        port - Port number (0 .. 65535).
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if port is illegal.
        See Also:
        listenHost(String)

      • listenPort

        public int listenPort()
        Get this job's listenPort property. The listenPort property specifies the port number at which the job itself will listen for connections. If not set, the default is 0, meaning the job will listen to an unused port.
        Returns:
        Port number (0 .. 65535).
        See Also:
        listenHost()

      • debug

        public void debug(Debug... debug)
        Print the given debugging messages for this job.
        Parameters:
        debug - Debugging message(s) to print, or null to print none.

      • debug

        public void debug(Set<Debug> debug)
        Print the given debugging messages for this job.
        Parameters:
        debug - Set of debugging message(s) to print, or null to print none.

      • debug

        public boolean debug(Debug debug)
        Determine if the given debugging message is activated for this job.
        Parameters:
        debug - Debugging message.
        Returns:
        True if debug is activated, false if deactivated.

      • jvmFlags

        public void jvmFlags(String... jvmFlags)
        Set this job's jvmFlags property. The JVM flags are included on the command line of the JVM that runs each task in this job. (The JVM flags are not included on the command line of the JVM that runs the job process itself.)
        Parameters:
        jvmFlags - JVM flags (zero or more).
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if jvmFlags is null or any element of jvmFlags is null.
        See Also:
        jvmFlags()

      • jvmFlags

        public String[] jvmFlags()
        Get this job's jvmFlags property. If not specified, the default is no JVM flags.
        Returns:
        Array of JVM flags (zero or more).
        See Also:
        jvmFlags(String[])

      • jar

        public void jar(File jarfile)
         throws IOException
        Set the JAR file that contains the class files needed by this job and its tasks.

        Note: The given JAR file replaces any previously specified JAR file; JAR files do not accumulate.

        Parameters:
        jarfile - JAR file.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if jarfile is null.
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred while reading the JAR file.

      • jar

        public File jar()
        Get the JAR file that contains the class files needed by this job and its tasks.
        Returns:
        JAR file, or null if none.

      • timeLimit

        public void timeLimit(int timeLimit)
        Set the time limit for this job. If the job has not finished within the given number of seconds after the first task starts, the job will automatically terminate itself.
        Parameters:
        timeLimit - Time limit (seconds), or ≤ 0 for no time limit.

      • timeLimit

        public int timeLimit()
        Get the time limit for this job. If the time limit is not specified, the default is no time limit.
        Returns:
        Time limit (seconds), or 0 if no time limit.
